review.title: A short note on estimating intelligence from user profiles in the context of universal psychometrics: prospects and caveats
review.abstract: There has been an increasing interest in inferring some personality traits from users and players in social networks and games, respectively. This goes beyond classical sentiment analysis, and also much further than customer profiling. The purpose here is to have a characterisation of users in terms of personality traits, such as openness, conscientiousness, extraversion, agreeableness, and neuroticism. While this is an incipient area of research, we ask the question of whether cognitive abilities, and intelligence in particular, are also measurable from user profiles. However, we pose the question as broadly as possible in terms of subjects, in the context of universal psychometrics, including humans, machines and hybrids. Namely, in this paper we analyse the following question: is it possible to measure the intelligence of humans and (non-human) bots in a social network or a game just from their user profiles, i.e., by observation, without the use of interactive tests, such as IQ tests, the Turing test or other more principled machine intelligence tests?
histories: Keywords: intelligence; user profiles; cognitive abilities; social networks; universal psychometrics; games; virtual worlds
review.COMMENTS: Keywords: intelligence; user profiles; cognitive abilities; social networks; universal psychometrics; games; virtual worlds

metadata.title: A short note on estimating intelligence from user profiles in the context of universal psychometrics: prospects and caveats

sections.text: ar Xiv: 130 5,16 55v1 [cs.AI] 7There is an increasing interest in deriving some personality traits of users or players in social networks or games, going beyond the classical analysis of the offer and extending far beyond customer profiling, in order to achieve a characterization of users in terms of personality traits such as openness, conscientiousness, extraversion, acceptability and neuroticism. While this is an emerging field of research, we ask whether cognitive abilities and intelligence in particular can also be measured by user profiles. However, we ask the question in the context of universal psychometry, including humans, machines and hybrids, as broadly as possible. Namely, in this paper we analyze the fol-logical question: Is it possible to measure the intelligence of humans and (non-human) bots in a social network or a game solely on the basis of their user profiles, i.e. tests, interaction tests, intelligence:

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: This means that it is relatively easy to imitate someone and use anonymity, which means that (almost) anything can be recorded and then analyzed. As a result, virtual environments are an excellent playground for analyzing and comparing the behavior of humans and machines.

sections.heading: 2 Measuring cognitive abilities of humans and
sections.text: Machines: universal psychometry [20]. The evaluation of the cognitive abilities of biological beings has been similarly addressed by psychometry [47, 4] for humans and by cognitive science [63] and comparative psychology, although animals are also taken into account. When talking about machines, things are much more dispersed and immature: specific tests (Turing test [66, 57], the entire Turing test [62] and other sensory variations [56]), the bot prize [42], CAPTCHAs [68], the use of human IQ tests for machines [16, 18, 17, 61, 6, 5], the machine intelligence quotient [71, 2],...), contests (RL competition [70], Robocup [49], general game competition [21], the planning of the contest [54],...) and landmarks (Deep Blue [7, Watson [20] The universal intelligence tests and other] problems of the Turing.

sections.heading: 3 Measuring intelligence without profiles
sections.text: The best way to evaluate the intelligence of an agent (be it a human or a machine) in a virtual environment is to use an intelligence test (but not a CAPTCHA or Turing test variant, as discussed above), so we will review and examine how intelligence is measured without profiles (below) and with profiles (in the next section), and whether there are other ways to interact with the behavior of agents without actually performing tests.

sections.heading: 4 Measuring intelligence with profiles
sections.text: They are judged by what they are able to do or what they have done. Intelligence is usually associated with what they are able to do. Nevertheless, we often draw on skills by looking at what has been done. In the context of virtual environments, we can know what the user is doing, how they speak, what they say, what friends they have, what they buy, and so on. As it says in the introduction, there is a strong interest in extracting value from all this information, products and interfaces to this behavior. One type of information that has recently been extracted from user profiles is the user's personality, such as openness, extraversion, acceptance, acceptance, acceptance, acceptance.

There is a notion that has emerged from the previous works: the idea of a ‘universal (intelligence) test’, first illustrated in [30], as a test that could be administered to any kind of subject, of any speed, and interrupted anytime.
The notion of a ‘test for all’ is appealing and soon generated widespread interest [50, 3].
The notion of a ‘test for all’ is appealing and soon generated widespread interest [50, 3].
The extent and breadth of universal tests has been analysed in [13].

However, the notion of evaluating humans, animals and machines with the same principles has led to a new discipline called universal psychometrics [35, 34], defined as the general evaluation of cognitive abilities of any kind of subject (with or without universal tests).

metadata.abstractText: There has been an increasing interest in inferring some personality traits from users and players in social networks and games, respectively. This goes beyond classical sentiment analysis, and also much further than customer profiling. The purpose here is to have a characterisation of users in terms of personality traits, such as openness, conscientiousness, extraversion, agreeableness, and neuroticism. While this is an incipient area of research, we ask the question of whether cognitive abilities, and intelligence in particular, are also measurable from user profiles. However, we pose the question as broadly as possible in terms of subjects, in the context of universal psychometrics, including humans, machines and hybrids. Namely, in this paper we analyse the following question: is it possible to measure the intelligence of humans and (non-human) bots in a social network or a game just from their user profiles, i.e., by observation, without the use of interactive tests, such as IQ tests, the Turing test or other more principled machine intelligence tests?
